climbs.name: Train Time
climbs.fa: Gary Allan, Victor Marcus, John Hoffman, 1980s

content.description:
Testy finger crack climbing interspersed with quality face moves typifies this challenging line.

Besides being a massive sandbag at 11a, the rusted piton guarding a potential deck adds much excitement for your headspace. A bolt here would make a lot of sense, the 30+ year piton made this ascent possible but has earned an honorable discharge. A small offset nut can be placed before the piton and a 00 C3 2’-3’ after, but good luck getting these in while fully tensioned on committing layback and face moves. Other than this section, protection is great.

A flaring finger crack that looked locker from below awaits you after the initial difficulties. Easier climbing up and then right to a newer double anchor on an unknown (and difficult) sport climb that follows an arete immediately right allows one to easily bypass the original aged chains to this route.
content.protection: Small offset nuts, doubles of tiny cams to .75” and singles of 1-2”, two bolt anchor with lowering biners
content.location: An obvious crack line with a rusted piton 10’ up on the far left side of Train Time Wall

content.description: Start up the face 10ft. right of Physical Graffiti.  Make a few moves and pull up onto the ledge and clip the only bolt on the route.  From here follow the vein up through a series of bulges to the top.
content.location: 10 ft. right of Physical Graffiti (the large dihedral).

content.description:
A quality warm up for the wall.

Physical Graffiti climbs the two dihedrals 25ft right of Train Time.

Start off on the flake (lieback) until you get to the top of the right dihedral.  Step left into the left dihedral and stem your way up to the top/anchors.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3".  Bring a 4" and 5" if this is near your leading limit or you wanna sew it up.
content.location: 25ft. right of Train Time above the train tressel.

content.description:
Nicely-featured face with a height-dependent crux, making a long left-hand reach to a large, flat edge. Maybe a bit of a sandbag...

This route shares anchors with "Beers For Fears" and currently sports some fairly old-looking tat to lower off of.
content.location: Route with 4 bolts on the left side of the face. They look camo-ed, but that's rust!

content.description: High-quality line, featuring fairly continuous laybacking and a smattering of nice crimps on the right face. The gear at the bottom is a bit funky (offsets might help), then gets better.
content.location: Obvious right-leaning crack on the right side of the wall.

content.description:
Head up the slightly overhung face on positive hand and foot holds.

Clip the bolt and continue up the crack systems.  Work your way up the corner on the right and wandering finger crack on the left to a ledge 2/3 of the way to the top.

Utilize the horizontal crack for a last chance pro/cam placement before heading up the final slab to the anchors.
content.protection: 1 bolt, single rack to 2" (bring some small stuff for the finger crack)

content.description:
Quality route, aside from some janky gear in a somewhat hollow flake. Moving from the flake to the 2nd bolt isn't the crux, but isn't trivial either - proceed with caution. Otherwise, great movement on excellent rock, although maybe a sandbag (just like it's neighbor).

This route shares anchors with "Mai Tai Madness" and currently sports some fairly old-looking tat to lower off of.
content.location: Far left side of the wall, look for a bolt, to a horizontal flake, to 2 more bolts.

content.description: Climbs and protects better than it looks. Start up a left-facing flake, then switch to a right-facing flake at about 20' height. Shares anchors with "Express Line".
content.location: Far right side of the wall, just right of an obvious right-leaning crack.

content.description:
Start off up the blocky rock below the roof (below the crack system).

Pull through the roof into the crack system.  Follow the lieback/crack to the top.

Lower off the anchors.
